main.bio: I have always been fascinated with the boundless and infinite capabilities of computers which motivated me to pursue a future in Computer Science. Currently pursing internship oppurtunities for Winter 2026.

education.degree: Bachelor of Computer Science, Business Data Analytics Minor (Co-op)
education.description: Relevant Courses: OOP, Data Structures, Software System Development & Integration, Operating Systems

work.title: Software Engineer Co-op
work.description: Working closely with internal and external stakeholders to drive incident resolution, ensure compliance, and optimize end-to-end operational processes.
work.description2: Contributing to system and network design discussions, infrastructure security audits, and automation initiatives to improve platform resilience and agility.

work.title: Software Developer Intern
work.description: Developed a prototype neural network using TensorFlow for image classification to detect diseases in cow lymph nodes, trained on a dataset of over 3,500 annotated DICOM-formatted X-ray images.
work.description2: Designed and implemented a Python-based image format converter program, streamlining the preprocessing of DICOM images for training the neural network.

CIBC.introduction: During Summer 2025, I worked as a Software Engineer Co-op at CIBC in Toronto. My role involved collaborating with internal teams to drive incident resolution, ensure compliance, and optimize operational processes. This website reflects my work term experience, the skills I developed, and the lessons I will carry forward into future co-op terms.
CIBC.employer: CIBC (Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce) is one of Canada’s Big Five banks, headquartered in Toronto with over 45,000 employees worldwide. It offers a wide range of financial services including retail banking, business banking, wealth management, and capital markets. I worked within the Technology and Operations division, contributing to software engineering initiatives that directly support CIBC’s digital banking infrastructure.
CIBC.goals: My goals for this work term included: (1) Developing stronger skills in automated testing and CI/CD integration, (2) Gaining experience with large-scale system design and infrastructure, (3) Improving communication and collaboration skills in a professional environment. I successfully contributed automated Python test scripts and participated in system/network design discussions. While I met most of my goals, I would like to deepen my experience with containerization and cloud technologies in future terms.
CIBC.job: As a Software Engineer Co-op, I worked on building and maintaining automated testing frameworks using Python (pytest/unittest), integrated them into Jenkins pipelines, and contributed to discussions around infrastructure security and resilience. I also assisted with incident resolution and process optimization, which gave me exposure to both technical problem-solving and cross-team communication.
CIBC.conclusion: Overall, this work term at CIBC provided me with valuable technical and professional growth. I gained practical experience in automation, CI/CD, and system resilience, while also learning how to collaborate effectively within a large organization. Moving forward, I am excited to apply these skills in future co-op placements and academic projects.
CIBC.acknowledgments: I would like to thank my supervisor and colleagues at CIBC for their guidance and support throughout this term. Their mentorship and feedback greatly enhanced my learning experience.
